questions.text: A 62-year-old female with a history of breast cancer presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up. She has recently completed a course of chemotherapy that included doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, and paclitaxel. Shortly after her chemotherapy, she developed febrile neutropenia and was treated with filgrastim and cefepime. She also has a history of hypertension controlled with amlodipine. She now reports experiencing symptoms of shortness of breath, fatigue, and palpitations. An echocardiogram reveals her ejection fraction has decreased to 40%. What is the most likely drug-related cause of her reduced ejection fraction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Doxorubicin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all the options:
  • • A) Filgrastim: This drug is used to stimulate the production of neutrophils and is commonly used to treat febrile neutropenia. It is not generally associated with cardiomyopathy or a reduced ejection fraction.
  • • B) Doxorubicin: Doxorubicin is a chemotherapy agent known for its cardiotoxic effects, which can result in reduced ejection fraction and symptoms like shortness of breath, fatigue, and palpitations. Given the patient's recent chemotherapy regimen that included doxorubicin, this is the most likely cause of her decreased ejection fraction.
  • • C) Cefepime: This antibiotic is commonly used to treat bacterial infections, including those that may occur with febrile neutropenia. It is not typically associated with reduced ejection fraction or cardiomyopathy.
  • • D) Amlodipine: This drug is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension. While it has cardiovascular effects, it is not generally associated with a reduced ejection fraction or cardiomyopathy.

The patient reports taking lithium for the past year as part of his treatment plan. Recently, he also started taking hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. On examination, the patient has a fine tremor in both hands and is noted to have a serum lithium level of 2.8 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's elevated serum lithium level?

options.label: A
options.text: Additive diuretic effect of hydrochlorothiazide and lithium.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased renal reabsorption of lithium due to hydrochlorothiazide.

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased gastrointestinal absorption of lithium due to hydrochlorothiazide.

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased renal reabsorption of lithium due to hydrochlorothiazide.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Increased renal reabsorption of lithium due to hydrochlorothiazide.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all the options:
  • • A) Additive diuretic effect of hydrochlorothiazide and lithium: While both hydrochlorothiazide and lithium can have diuretic effects, this option doesn't directly explain the elevated serum lithium level. The primary concern here is the elevated lithium level, not an additive diuretic effect.
  • • B) Increased renal reabsorption of lithium due to hydrochlorothiazide: Hydrochlorothiazide can increase the renal reabsorption of lithium, leading to elevated serum lithium levels and symptoms of toxicity. This is the most likely explanation for the patient's elevated lithium level.
  • • C) Decreased gastrointestinal absorption of lithium due to hydrochlorothiazide: This option is misleading because decreased gastrointestinal absorption of lithium would lead to lower serum lithium levels, not higher.
  • • D) Hydrochlorothiazide-induced enhancement of lithium metabolism: This is also a distractor. Enhancement of lithium metabolism would typically result in reduced serum lithium levels, not elevated levels.
  • • Therefore, the most likely cause for the elevated serum lithium level and symptoms in this patient is the increased renal reabsorption of lithium due to hydrochlorothiazide.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who received a kidney transplant three months ago is admitted to the hospital with high-grade fever, malaise, and abdominal discomfort. On examination, he exhibits right upper quadrant tenderness. Lab investigations reveal abnormal liver enzymes, and a blood culture returns positive for cytomegalovirus (CMV). His current immunosuppressive regimen includes tacrolimus. What is the primary pharmacological action of tacrolimus that might have predisposed this patient to develop a CMV infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Inhibition of calcineurin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all the options:
  • • A) Inhibition of calcineurin: Tacrolimus acts by inhibiting calcineurin, which plays a pivotal role in T-cell activation. This immunosuppressive action can make the patient susceptible to infections such as CMV.
  • • B) Blockade of IL-2 receptor: This is a mechanism of other immunosuppressive drugs like basiliximab but not tacrolimus. Therefore, it is not relevant to the patient's current condition.
  • • C) IMP dehydrogenase inhibition: This is the mechanism of mycophenolate mofetil, another immunosuppressive drug. It is not applicable to tacrolimus.
  • • D) Dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase inhibition: This mechanism is associated with drugs like leflunomide but is not relevant to the action of tacrolimus.
  • • Thus, the primary pharmacological action of tacrolimus that might have predisposed this patient to develop a CMV infection is the inhibition of calcineurin.

Symptoms of theophylline toxicity include nausea, vomiting, tremors, seizures, and tachycardia. In severe cases, theophylline toxicity can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and seizures. Other drugs that can interact with theophylline include ciprofloxacin, erythromycin, and fluvoxamine.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) consults his physician for treatment options. The physician recommends the use of rabeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor. Which of the following statements about proton pump inhibitors is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Proton pump inhibitors are available as enteric-coated tablets.

options.label: B
options.text: Proton pump inhibitors act from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Proton pump inhibitors are inactive at neutral pH.

options.label: D
options.text: Proton pump inhibitors should be taken half an hour before food

questions.correct_answer: B. Proton pump inhibitors act from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Proton pump inhibitors act from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells.

Explanation:

  • • A) Proton pump inhibitors are available as enteric-coated tablets: This statement is TRUE. The enteric coating allows the medication to pass through the stomach without being destroyed by the stomach acid, eventually dissolving in the intestine for absorption.
  • • B) Proton pump inhibitors act from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells: This statement is FALSE. Proton pump inhibitors, including rabeprazole, act from the acidic canaliculus inside the gastric parietal cell, not from the luminal side.
  • • C) Proton pump inhibitors are inactive at neutral pH: This statement is TRUE. Proton pump inhibitors are prodrugs that are activated in an acidic environment, which allows them to act specifically on the stomach's acid-secreting cells.
  • • D) Proton pump inhibitors should be taken half an hour before food: This statement is TRUE. Taking proton pump inhibitors around 30 minutes before eating ensures better activation of the drug, as the stomach starts producing acid in response to eating, thereby optimizing the drug's efficacy.
  • • Therefore, the statement that is INCORRECT regarding proton pump inhibitors is that they act from the luminal side of gastric parietal cells.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has a high affinity for 5-HT2 receptors in the brain, does not cause extrapyramidal dysfunction or agranulocytosis, and is reported to increase the risk of significant QT prolongation?

questions.text: All of the following limitations of typical tricyclic antidepressants has been overcome by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors except?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: High risk of cardiac arrhythmias and seizures in overdose

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Delayed response

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) typically have fewer anticholinergic, sedative, and hypotensive side effects than tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs). SSRIs have a safer profile in terms of overdose than TCAs. Overdose with TCAs can lead to severe cardiac arrhythmias and seizures, while overdose with SSRIs is generally much less dangerous. Both SSRIs and TCAs typically take a few weeks to exert their full therapeutic effects. Thus, the delayed response is not a limitation that has been overcome by SSRIs. SSRIs generally have less of an impact on metabolic parameters, including acid-base balance, than TCAs, so they're less likely to cause metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to his primary care physician complaining of a persistent, dull, gnawing pain in his upper abdomen. He mentions the discomfort has been on and off for several months now and seems to worsen on an empty stomach. He denies any changes in bowel habits or any symptoms of nausea, vomiting, or weight loss. His medical history is notable for osteoarthritis and he has been taking aspirin regularly for the past 5 years for pain relief. The physician suspects that chronic use of aspirin may have led to the development of a peptic ulcer. Which of the following drugs would be the best choice for treating this patient's suspected peptic ulcer disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Omeprazole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and is generally considered the first-line treatment for peptic ulcer disease, including ulcers that are suspected to have been caused by chronic NSAID (such as aspirin) use. Omeprazole and other PPIs work by irreversibly inhibiting the hydrogen/potassium ATPase pump in the stomach lining, which is responsible for the final step in the production of gastric acid. This reduces the amount of acid in the stomach, allowing ulcers to heal and reducing the likelihood of their formation. Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analog and is most specific drug for NSAID-induced ulcers. It acts by increasing bicarbonate and mucus production in the stomach, thereby protecting the stomach lining. However, it's often not the first choice due to its side effects (such as diarrhea) and the need for frequent dosing (four times daily). Pirenzepine is a selective M1 muscarinic receptor antagonist that inhibits gastric acid secretion, but it is less effective and commonly used than PPIs or H2 blockers in peptic ulcer disease. Ranitidine is a H2-receptor antagonist and while it also decreases the production of stomach acid, it is not as potent as PPIs like omeprazole.
  • • Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and is generally considered the first-line treatment for peptic ulcer disease, including ulcers that are suspected to have been caused by chronic NSAID (such as aspirin) use.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement about the use of loperamide in the management of diarrhea:

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to control diarrhea irrespective of its etiology

options.label: B
options.text: It should be used only as a short term measure after ensuring that enteroinvasive organisms are not involved

options.label: C
options.text: It is used as adjuvant to antimicrobial therapy of diarrhea

options.label: D
options.text: It is the drug of choice in Traveller’s diarrhea

questions.correct_answer: B. It should be used only as a short term measure after ensuring that enteroinvasive organisms are not involved
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. It should be used only as a short term measure after ensuring that enteroinvasive organisms are not involved

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Loperamide is an anti-diarrheal agent that works by slowing the movement of the intestines, which helps to reduce the frequency of bowel movements. It is not used to control diarrhea irrespective of its etiology. For instance, if diarrhea is caused by certain types of infections (such as those involving enteroinvasive organisms), loperamide can potentially worsen the situation by delaying the elimination of the pathogens from the gut. Loperamide is used as a short-term measure to manage symptoms of acute diarrhea. It is especially important to confirm that enteroinvasive organisms are not involved, as using loperamide in such cases could be harmful. Loperamide is not used as an adjuvant to antimicrobial therapy. It is primarily used for symptomatic relief. Loperamide is not the drug of choice for Traveller's diarrhea, especially when the diarrhea is severe, bloody, or accompanied by fever. Antibiotics are often the preferred treatment in such cases.
